review_title: JPAL South Asia Was a Terrible Place to Work
pros: The people. Some of the most hardworking and intelligent co workers I've ever had. Chai breaks in the Ahmedabad office were a particular highlight. Would have great conversations with Co-RAs, PAs, and even senior survey staff. Everything from politics to pop culture was on the table. Everyone was all-in on the mission and the research.
cons: My PIs and many of my RA friends' PIs were abusive. For many of the JPAL RAs though this is their first job, and they don't really know how to speak up for themselves. The organizational structure was such that it was rare if ever that it intervened to protect RAs from abusive American PIs. The general structure of the organization is extremely exploitative and PIs get much more from the experience than RAs. Despite the fact that the RAs are literally indispensable for the research they are literally relegated to a footnote in the paper. In truth RAs bring more value to the research than the PIs. The worst part is that that RAs take this exploitation with the hope that their PIs will give them rla recommendation letter for grad school in the US. Sadly these letters are not as forthcoming as RAs initially expect. To think that students in the US can get the same letters simply for doing well in the professors class, a class that meets two times a week for an hour and a half is a level of unfairness that is truly disgusting. I am the only person I am aware of from my time at JPAL that ever ended up in a top notch PhD program in the USA, out of almost 10 to 15 close friends who were RAs at the time. A few went to the USA for MBAs but this was the exception not the norm. I am currently un my 4th year at MIT.

pros: - I had a good PI so it was hectic busy and very productive and great place to learn but I saw many other RAs flailing and mostly wasting their time under PIs who never responded to emails, were never around and were barely aware that their research was ongoing in India.
cons:
- despite my PI providing me with an amazing opportunity to grow, my PI was terrifying to actually speak to and work with, the hours were crazy, I barely had any life outside of work and finally, I had to do a lot of personal counselling (during and after my job) to undo a lot of the mental trauma and deep insecurity that surfaces when working such ungodly hours for so little pay and when working for a PI who was so smart/terrifying/demanding. 
- I didn't know that RAs basically had to say yes to every single thing that the PI asks - wish I had known this before joining J-PAL
- J-PAL has a huge problem with hiring a certain kind of foreign-MPP/development studies, "cool" South-Delhi/ South-Bombay/South-Bangalore Econ grads who are all unanimously upper-caste and have a very particular way of interacting with the surveyors, with the staff and each other. For someone not from this socio-economic group, it is a bit isolating. If you are from this socio-economic group - you will have a fantastic time with all your "like-minded" people. The other RAs and managers are all very smart and fun but honestly, everyone sounds and looks and talks the same and it's difficult to get other perspectives.

review_title: Stressful, need thick skin to be an executive assistant
pros: Lots of opportunities for interesting seminars in the office and at MIT. Good benefits. Coworkers are extremely smart and friendly, it is easy to get along and have a good time with everyone. There are plenty of fun work events. Lots of work/project opportunities, always something going on and some way to get involved.
cons:
Managers/coworkers definitely want you to succeed and hope that you can get by, but top-down pressure severely hinders their ability to advocate for you. Management has unrealistic expectations from staff and hire one person to do the job of several people. There are varying levels of managers for a team, but sometimes not enough associate level staff for the backbone of the work. This results in everyone being overburdened and not assigning the appropriate work to a team member. There are several opportunities for professional development, but limited time is allowed to actually take them which hinders upward mobility.

Workaholics thrive and are encouraged at J-PAL. Senior staff hire people who are driven by J-PAL's mission, overqualified, and young. While this means that staff are dedicated and exceptional at what they do, it fosters a stressful, overbearing work environment. Even at an 8:30-5:30 office, many staff work late and it may even be the norm in some cases. 

The stress I felt from the person I supported was detrimental to my health. If you want to be an executive assistant here you need to be thick-skinned, clear-headed, and willing to put up with a lot.

pros: At J-PAL, there is incredible potential to contribute to development impacts across a variety of sectors, globally. My former colleagues include some of the brightest and hardest working people I know.
cons: On the down side, I've seen many people depart over time. Primarily, senior management's expectations of staff are out of touch (read: work/life balance). Add to this, compensation is far from truly competitive. A common refrain is, "but the access to people/experience/professional development." Yes, there are opportunities, but there are also many limitations. One important one is limited potential for growth.

review_title: Network of affiliates or corporate organization? J-PAL is confused. SO, use it as a stepping stone or get stuck.
pros:
1. Top notch data skills after two years of experience

2. You will be positioned to work with a team of field staff and professors. So you get to understand on ground realities and connect them theoretically.

3.  Project management skills will be well developed. Especially at such a young age, when the RAs get to cal the shots on the field - you learn a lot about work prioritization, handling partner/stakeholders, multi tasking, dos and don'ts of research operations and rolling out RCT etc.
cons:
1. No standardization with respect to payment policies - payment structures, perks and benefits are different amongst the field staff or consultants which is HUGE problem as an organization. 

2. Poor leadership among the middle and senior management. There are very few people in the senior management who have a spine and speak up when things are wrong. Else, everyone believes -  fall in line or fall out.

3. Zero organizational culture and no effort to move towards one.

pros: There is a lot to learn at this job, and some of your coworkers will be outstanding. This organization has done remarkable things in the past, but I am not sure what the future holds for it.
cons:
I worked as a manager here for over 2 years and boy, was this an unhappy place to be. First, I need to clarify: this is a huge organization. There are offices all over the world. I worked in the Cambridge office.

The overall executive director of this organization verbally abuses his employees to the point that they literally cry (this did not happen to me, but to many others). It is remarkable to see this type of treatment tolerated in a modern-day workforce, but it is allowed because it is really not that out of line with the culture.

The culture, is, in general, extremely hierarchical. Employees lower down the ladder are directly devalued, to the point that it is assumed they are not going to stay for over two years. Managers are also not treated very well, and there is little actual room for advancement. During my time at the organization over half of the managers left. Several others left in the months after I departed.

review_title: Surprisingly entrepreneurial, need to have people/project management skills beforehand
pros:
- Very interesting work in India. Due to the professors' stature and connections, you can get access to some top policymakers, and the project results have a better chance of being implemented than many other NGOs. 
- Work with top-notch professors, get stellar recommendations if you do well. Almost everyone gets into a top grad school in economics or policy (masters or PhD)
- Work and lifestyle is fairly entrepreneurial -- you manage your own time, and often a team of staff. Should have some people management skills (and like managing people) to do well in JPAL, even though it attracts aspiring PhDs.
cons:
- Support and directions could be weak because professors are far away, but JPAL has beefed up its project management structure in the recent 2 years. Hence, there are now more senior managers than before to oversee the young RAs and help them deal with management problems. 
- Choose professor carefully, not necessarily project -- not all JPAL professors are equal in terms of the strength of recommendation at different schools and how willing they are to write great ones. I would focus on choosing the right professor (and do some groundwork and who's good to work with) instead of the most interesting project area. 
- Non-Indian origin RAs are no longer hired due to change in work visa policies -- very sad!

review_title: People don't want to work here -- just the facts
pros: This job has decent benefits despite its generally low pay, and many positions offer the chance to travel interesting places. RAs use this as a stepping stone to PhD programs.
cons:
J-PAL is forming a committee to “improve” the organization’s online ratings, so I thought it was time to share my review.

I’ve been reluctant to do this before now, in part because I often find it hard to trust negative reviews. Was this person’s experience an isolated incident? A bad culture fit? I’m also not sure how to share my experiences without revealing my identity. 

So, I thought the best story I could tell to prospective employees is to give objective facts. Below is a list of all the permanent staff who have left the organization in the last 12 months (April 2017 to April 2018):

Global office:

Directors (1)
Managers (5)
Associates (4)
Administrative (4)

(Total departed: 14, Current office size: 37)

North America office:

Managers (5)
Associates (3)
Administrative (1)

(Total departed: 9, Current office size: 23)

Between the two offices there was about 40% turnover in permanent staff in a single year. The organization is doing fine financially—it hired or is hiring replacements for everyone leaving. In the list above I only counted permanent staff, so I didn’t count research assistants who often sign on for two-year terms (if I did, the number would be higher). I also didn’t count the North America Executive Director, who left during this time. Many of these people found working at this place so unpleasant that they left without having other jobs lined up.

Honestly, I’m planning to add myself to their number.

review_title: J-PAL one of the best organisation
pros: Very flexible and good working environment
cons: Salary Rise is very slow and internal politics

pros:
. Newcomers are friendly, you'll make friends easily.
. Opportunities to travel (for some).
. Senior leaders are reachable.
. Opportunities to get substantial raises (if you get close to those with power).
cons:
. Low pay for newcomers and analysts.
. If you're applying for an analyst or associate position, better stay away.  They will not offer you stability and will hire you as an external consultant.
. A lot of favoritism. 

And the worst: MISMANAGEMENT!  
This is an organization with almost same amount of high-level executives as analysts.  I've seen people getting hired, who a couple of months later got fired because someone did not check if they had the money to pay them.  Same with promotions and raises, they explain to the analyst there is not enough money for salary increases, but they do have money for increasing those for managers or promoting them to directors.

pros: Some of the staff are truly great. A good place to start a career.
cons: Change in the organization is slow, lack of autonomy, narrow mindedness

pros: Career driven nice work excellent
cons: none i coul think it was a nice experience

pros:
Work with phenomenal academic researchers/Experience to observe how randomized evaluations are done/Data Analysis/Great letters of recommendation for graduate schools

It really depends what you want to get out of the job position.  There is room for enough growth as a researcher. You end up learning how to handle pressure.  You get to enhance your management skills.  You also get an opportunity to decide whether you really want to devote the rest of your life doing randomized evaluations.  If you want to be in academia or want to pursue development as a major field of your study, I would strongly recommend gaining at least a year long experience with JPAL.
cons:
Inadequate salary by global standards (if you work in a developing country)/ Stressful job - need to work even in the weekends

Although pros clearly outweigh cons, you should be mentally prepared that this is not going to be a standard 8:30-5 job.  Honestly, because you are surrounded my fellow JPAL employees (depending upon where are based out of), you get used to the culture of the organization. Plus, while socializing with your fellow colleagues, you end up learning a lot.  Be prepared that you will be working all the time, literally.

pros: Best good cmpany all wats
cons: Vad bad bit good always

review_title: A good first experience, but the professors are self-serving, career growth is minimal
pros: A lot of responsibility given to you early on which helps hone useful skills and experiences. The employees are young and enthusiastic.
cons:
Major gap between the professors (PIs) and lower/entry-level employees. Experience is based purely on the professors the RA ends up working with since quality control is low and no systems are in place to check professors or ensure uniformity in experiences or accountability of the PIs.
Suffers from usual international development issues of money being pumped into projects that might not be very useful and which only cater to the professor's tenure needs. Have seen PIs tweak data and field experiences to appeal to donors.

pros: There will never be another time in most J-PAL employees' lives when they can live in the field, with nothing else in their lives except helping to impliment programs that could potentially make a difference in needy people's lives.
cons: There is a reason why people do not do this for their entire life.  The organization requires constant work, gives little feedback and largely leaves RA's alone to fend for themselves, except when in emergencies it sends more senior staff to babysit them.  There is no work life balance and very little contact with research.  It is a lot of busy work, and I feel that many new comers are not accustomed to this kind of work.  The salaries, benefits and balance aren't good enough to encourage more mature applicants.

review_title: Don't join as your first job out of college
pros: - I can't think of any tbh
cons:
- No oversight
- No professional development opportunities. PI's don't care about their RA's professional development, and if you are joining this position for a letter of recommendation - beware. It is very difficult to form meaningful relationships with the PI's, especially if they are senior level PIs. 
- Chances of being stagnated for long periods of time. You will be wasting your precious time just doing nothing in the "field", which are often times remote locations in a developing country. This can be frustrating, especially if you are looking forward to developing your skills/learning new things for your own growth. 
- The opportunity cost of missing out by being isolated is huge. 
- Don't expect colleagues or PI's to be friendly or helpful if you feel lost at your job in your first few months.

pros: Innovative and important work in international development, super friendly colleagues, lots of opportunities for professional development and international travel, very accessible senior leadership from managers to executive director, open culture of up and down feedback and coaching, work from home Thursdays, pizza lunches and happy hours, almost no evening or weekend emails.
cons: Not much work directly with majority of affiliated professors. Steep learning curve on existing research. Hours can be long when special projects come from regions or grants. Salary is average for non-profit world but don't expect to save a ton given Cambridge rents (though MIT benefits are nice). Be prepared for long and cold winter coming from warmer weather.

review_title: One of the leading global centers of development
pros:
- Great people. You'll be working with smart, motivated, hard-working people with - on the average - a great sense of humor.
- Young organization. This may be a pro or con, but most of the organization is young (20s-30s), highly educated, friendly.
- Technical expertise. You'll get technical knowledge on how to run RCTs; you'll learn everything from power calculations to questionnaire design. These are incredibly marketable skills these days.
- Travel. Even if you're working in the Global HQ at MIT, you'll still likely be asked to travel (sometimes extensively - 2-3 months) to projects in the field. 
- Training. There's a 1-week training which many staff end up attending twice: first, as a student, and then, as a Teaching Assistant or Lecturer. This is a great opportunity.
- Glamor/fame. J-PAL is considered one of the best development organizations out there, so obviously having it on your resume is a huge bonus. J-PAL alumni have gone into top-tier PhD programs, to the World Bank, USAID, Social Impact, and so on.
cons:
- Global positions are a little better-treated than positions with the regional offices. The former are better paid, have access to MIT's amazing ecosystem, access to great benefits (again, through MIT), slightly more reasonable work culture (things usually die down by 6:30pm) and can even get more facetime with the "famous" PIs like Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee. Regional office positions (J-PAL LAC, South Asia, Africa, Europe, SE Asia), instead, are relatively underpaid, overworked (late late hours are normalized - 8pm, 9pm at the office), and sometimes isolating (e.g. if you're working alone on a project in a remote part of the country). That said, regional office positions (field positions) are probably much more valuable to growing your skill set - you learn a LOT more by facing the challenges (of which there are many!) of running an RCT on the ground.
- Parallel track: to PhD or not to PhD. Many people use J-PAL as a springboard into their own PhD programs. As such, they accept low pay and hard working conditions in order to get a letter of recommendation from their PI. For those not intending to do a PhD, career progression can be vague or absent.
- Professor-managers: This is changing somewhat, with the introduction and beefing up of middle management positions. But PIs still act as the ultimate "bosses" of J-PAL and this can be problematic. You have to realize that, often, these are people who have never left a university setting - as such, they're often not great managers. They may have unreasonable expectations, they might forget to think about your career development and training, they might also be insensitive or harsh in their emails. A big part of the job is "managing upwards", since many of these PIs are, well, a little "disconnected" from the realities of the workplace, to put it mildly.

pros: I worked at J-PAL right out of college. The degree of autonomy and the amount of guidance from the organisation (i.e. managers and professors) was extremely balanced. Apart from high quality of research J-PAL exposes you to, there is a vibrant culture of work that lays a solid foundation to work-place practices for the future. That being said, like any other institution /organisation, it is up to an individual to make the most of it.
cons: Hiring at J-PAL is per project -- experiences vary because of many factors- the stage of the project, PIs, location, to name a few! If the project is slowly moving, it can be extremely frustrating. If the location is very remote, there are other challenges. These factors are really not too much in your control and sometimes may not be to your liking.

pros:
I had a terrific PI who was super invested, concerned about my career and my aspirations and HELPED a TON (and continues to help even years later)

I don't know a single person who left J-PAL who doesn't miss J-PAL 

J-PAL has such great people, it really was an immense privilege to work with a bunch of hopeful, hard working young people 

The work is intense (if you enjoy the work, perhaps you won't mind not having a social life for 1-2 years), valued and gives you so much to think about/mull over
cons:
Some project RAs did basically no work, just sat around waiting for months for directives from their very remote and inaccessible PIs - that can happen at J-PAL

Some PIs were very scary and intimidating to work with and it shows in the mental health of the RAs

job_title: Field-Based Research Associate in New Delhi
pros:
You acquire skills that are transferable to other monitoring and evaluation jobs. 
You learn to work with remote supervision.
It gives you a flavour for what doing a PhD economics might be like, especially if you plan to do field experiments. 
It is an excellent drill in learning the mechanics of RCTs. 
Access to two excellent email groups: The Random help group, and the jpal ipa alumni group.
cons:
Being a field RA is a very isolating position to be in. You have to deal with pretty unpleasant situations. Navigating relationships can be very tricky especially in managing field staff. PIs can be a bit out of touch regarding field realities. You have to be on call almost 24/7--although no one explicitly asks of you, it's impossible not work on Saturdays when your field team is working. 
Pay is very low.

review_title: Interesting and relevant work; supportive and collaborative work environment
pros:
- Collaborative and team-oriented environment (Policy team)
- Supportive professional development; for example, management is willing to fund professional coursework, trainings, travel to skills-building conferences, and multi-week field research trips
- Interesting and diverse day to day work; good mix of analysis and writing, public speaking, project management, and both individual and team-oriented work
- Dedicated time each week to "green space" for attending lectures, reading papers, etc.
- Good work-life balance (if you advocate for it and manage your time well)
- Salaries are competitive for the nonprofit field
- Incredibly smart, driven, and collaborative colleagues
cons:
- Must take initiative to manage your time and portfolio well; it's easy to get overloaded. As with most nonprofits, there's lots of work and limited resources.
- Staff is not very diverse

review_title: Upper management is out of touch with staff
pros: J-PAL has a great mission, with some amazing staff around the globe. They hire talented employees and MIT provides decent benefits.
cons: The current senior management either doesn't know how unhappy staff are, or is choosing to ignore it. Multiple people have quit without having a new job and there's no discussion of the real problem - and overworked staff, little to no room for advancement, micromanagement from the highest levels of the organization and a false belief that a good mission is reason enough not to compensate people for hard work.

review_title: Interesting research and management opportunities in the first 3 months, after that you feel under-paid and over-worked.
pros:
Prestige of the organization and its MIT and Harvard connections
Recommendations from top professors
Working with the brightest minds in Economic Development
Interesting work - at first
Opportunities to live abroad
cons:
Truly under-paid and over-over worked
No appreciation for any personal time you may want, thought taking vacations (if you find the money) don't seem to be a problem
Management is very poor
Training is horrendous and unhelpful
You're pretty much expected to enter a PhD program after a year, max 2, and there is little other room for advancement

review_title: Variety and opportunities for professional growth
pros: Great way to launch a career in international development. Meaningful work, lots of variety, lots of travel. I found managers who cared about my professional development and they helped me carve out a path of increasing responsibility and new challenges. (However, not everyone had this experience, I know some of my colleagues felt limited and overworked.) Good exit options to MPP, PhD and other grad programs as well as other international development orgs
cons: Nonprofit salaries and nonprofit disorganization. The big bosses are academic researchers, and they have the final say on things even when that doesn't make sense. Workload/expectations can be high, but this varies between roles and offices

review_title: Low pay, high brand but above all great experience - for a time.
pros:
1. Poverty concerns all of us. Understanding it is rewarding in an intellectual and moral sense. 
2. Great professors, brand. Useful for those who want a recommendation for PhD/MPP admission.
3. Great managerial position with enough scope for on-the-spot thinking and learning.
cons:
1. Low pay. This is the flip-side of pro #2.
2. Low focus on intellectual value-add - focus is to get the data for the profs. One can start feeling like an automaton soon.

pros:
J-PAL is a well known organisation especially in the fields of academia and research.  From early on you begin to work with Economists who are at the top of their domains from some of the best universities in the world. 
Projects at J-PAL are managed like small organisations - it gives you a chance to get great exposure to setting up an organisation, hiring field staff, training and managing the entire field operations.
cons: Very often people are sent to remote locations, where they are at the beck and call of the Economists.  expectations are not managed well and most of the RA and RMs and project Managers are overworked.

review_title: Best place to up-skill oneself, even with all systemic flaws. Be open to listening.
pros:
1. Wonderful fieldwork experience. Can't get better than J-PAL
2. Rigorous team management skills. Too bad if you consider yourself a snobbish prude who has only excelled in academics. Management is an essential part of the job. Learn it here. 
3. Develop brilliant insights on data science and management.
cons:
1. Not many career trajectory discussions - can leave the RA a bit puzzled and insecure. 

2. Salary low BUT it's recompensed with additional skills to increases earning capacity in the future.

review_title: Work no more than 1-2 Years as a Research Associate. Not for management positions
pros:
-The peers. J-PAL manages to attract very driven, talented, and innovative peers. Most of your learning  and growth comes from them as opposed to the Principal Investigators. This is so  because Principal Investigators mostly don't spend much time in mentoring or even communicating outside the weekly calls (there are some exceptions of course).

- You get a very hands on experience on good data collection for development research. It also gives you an opportunity to see how a research problem unfolds on the ground from start, something that you don't quite get a flavor of by just reading papers.

-You will get a good experience in project management. But this depends on  project and PI.
cons:
-Senior management is woefully inadequate, and ill-equipped to mentor Research Managers, and Senior Research Associates. This has especially worsened over the last couple of years. You will hardly ever see any senior management in any field office. They are cut off from the ground realities. Office politics takes precedence over transparency in hiring,  and evaluation process. Towing the line is rewarded.

-The structural issue is that Principal Investigators wield a lot of power in key decisions in the organization but they are not accountable for anything.  They bring in the business  and so it is incentive incompatible for the senior management to not do anything that upsets that. As a consequence, hiring, evaluation, and work life balance suffers. Even mentoring Research Associates suffer as the relationship between the Research Team and Principal Investigators are fairly exploitative.

-The working hours are insane with little support, unless you are lucky enough to have very considerate managers, PIs.

-Low pay and terrible work hours. Job itself  can be very isolating although excellent peers do help. 
 
-Organization will push you to uphold its values but not necessarily support you for doing so. 

-There is no career path beyond 1 or 2 years.  Get an experience for 1-2 years and get out. 

-Any effort to improve accountability falls on deaf ears and the best ones have tried.

review_title: Be at a front seat in policy informing, bringing rigorous evidence to the table of senior government officials.
job_title: Senior Policy Manager in New Delhi
pros: A fantastic opportunity to partner with governments in a meaningful way, be heard, and be involved in their policy design discussions and decisions.
cons: A restriction is the amount of RCT evidence that is also relevant for governments to use, this means it is a pretty slim set of options we can offer to governments, when their ask and needs are usually much much wider.

review_title: great mission, but not a great place to work for
pros:
-a working environment with energetic, mostly young colleagues who really believe in the mission of the organization
-flexible workplace policies in terms of taking leaves or working from outside the office
-opportunity to travel
cons:
-a lot of repetitive tasks on the job even though the organization likes to hire people with high level of technical skills 
-little room for professional growth
-complete power imbalance between economists and lower-level employees
-feeling under-valued and exploited most of the time: the organization culture expects a lot of hours and efforts put into tasks but appreciation is hard to come by and reviews of completed tasks can be overly critical over small details
-strongly recommend against joining this organization unless you are sure you want to join a econ/policy phD after working there for 1-2 yrs

review_title: Unparalleled and overwhelming learning experience - but for a limited time only.
pros: There is a lot of on-the-ground experience to be had, and a lot of opportunity to learn about how research and development projects are implemented. It is an amazing opportunity to gain a lot of knowledge and to improve your technical skills, and to see what you've learned in a classroom play out in real life. There isn't a comparable experience in international development or impact evaluation research. Fellow research staff and field staff are all young, motivated, smart, interesting people, who form strong communities in each of the field offices and nationally.  If the PIs are involved, generous, and supportive, it can be a wonderful learning experience - it depends entirely on the PIs.
cons:
Low-pay, overwork, thankless. 

The PIs have complete power in the relationship to assign work, and some even delegate their intellectual work, including designing experiments and interventions, writing grant applications, deliverables and papers, for which J-PAL staff get footnote credit. Given the time difference between professors in the USA and regional field offices, work is sometimes assigned in the afternoon USA time to be completed immediately, requiring RAs to occasionally pull all-nighters to get things done. The PI power dynamic relative to the employees means that the personalities and characters of the PIs can completely shape the employees experience. 

As for the organization itself (as versus the PIs), the management has a focus on getting projects done rather than on supporting or respecting employees. The pay scale is very low for the industry, is purposefully not transparent, and different roles are not paid based on education, work experience or workload. Additionally, the regional field offices have work conditions such that RAs are sometimes exposed to infectious disease and threats of violence.  The organization has expanded so rapidly that management has not been able to put structures in place to cope with these problems. 

Despite this, the pros really do outweigh the cons - but for about a year or so. It is a fantastic learning experience. After about a year, though, burnout sets in from overwork, repetitive tasks, and feelings of exploitation. 

Advice: apply to J-PAL, do the job for a year, then get your letter of recommendation, apply to grad school and get out.

review_title: Good place to gain first-hand experience conducting RCTs
pros: It depends a lot on your supervisor, as you'll be working one-on-one with him. Your experience can be very rewarding or awful if you find yourself working with an arrogant and disorganised supervisor.
cons: Again, for most RA work, J-PAL (at least in Europe) doesn't really get that much involved in the work you're doing, so you have no one to see if things with your supervisor don't work out as well as expected.

pros: Interesting projects, research opportunities, learning new stuff, academic environment, talented colleagues and superiors
cons: Not anything serious in particular. People deciding to work for J-PAL are motivated enough to bother less about the traveling part, or relatively low compensation as compared to private sector companies.Work-life balance does take a hit, but as majority of researchers are bachelors looking for some experience before enrolling in a university, it doesn't really matter.

review_title: J-PAL SA was a good learning experience
pros: You get to learn quite a bit about research and the challenges in the developing world.
cons:
There is a bit of disconnect between what the professors want to do and what is allowed at J-PAL. 
There are some growing pains related to costs of running projects, but hopefully they got sorted soon.

review_title: Admin Associate at Global (based at MIT)
pros: Organization is supportive of professional development and invests a lot in its employees. Very well run from the top down. Being based at MIT gives a lot of additional benefits.
cons: Coworkers are very hardworking which can be intense at times. Compensation isn't high, but it's good for development work and feeling good about the mission makes up for the salary.

pros: Hands-on experience with  field work for development economics, which is priceless for an Economics student looking to pursue further studies. An internship is just about good enough to get an insight into how field work is organized and implemented for research.
cons: Quality of experience strongly depends on the RA and PI (I got lucky), and the tasks can seem repetitive after a while.

review_title: Great flexible company with passionate people
pros: J-PAL has a very flexible work environment. Staff are frequently allowed to work from home or can easily slip out for a few hours for a doctors appointment or long lunch. There is also a lot of dedication to professional development, and the staff that you will be working with are all very passionate and wonderful people.
cons: Sometimes the work requires very long hours

review_title: Overall, a great place to work!
pros:
1. Great exposure to primary research.
2. Access to a network of some very decorated professors. Good recommendation can land you very good colleges easily.
3. You do a little bit of everything - HR, Financial Management, Capacity Building, Data Cleaning, Analysis
4. Highly flexible work schedule.
cons:
1. Limited Growth in terms of both experience and skill set.
2. Inhuman working hours at times.

pros: Working with smart people, having the opportunity to work closely with some of the best researchers in the area, doing interesting and relevant work, informal and dynamic athmosphere, opportunity to travel
cons: relatively low salary, very high turnover (especially for research assistants/juniorpositions) , some projects fail which can be frustrating, RAs need to work very hard in some cases without receiving recognition

pros:
You learn field management.
If the stars align you learn Stata
cons: Work is highly dependant on the project. Always on call. Senior management is incompetent. Even though the research deals with people, you aren't treated like you're a human. PIs are treated like gods. Some Managers don't stand up against the PIs even when RMs themselves have complaints. They barely stands up for the RAs.

review_title: Great place to work and learn
pros: Unparalleled training on impact evaluation and rigorous research. Mission driven staff,  very talented colleagues.
cons: The organization is at the intersection of academia and policy and does not always navigate that divide well (i.e. academics are often more concerned about publishing than social impact and the reverse is often the case for staff).

pros: Great independent project management experience, opportunities to work for top development economists
cons: Long hours/no weekends during busy periods, can be difficult to take vacation time, little support/feedback from supervisors

review_title: RA and senior officer is very gentle and supporting and its payment process is very good
pros: I feel working with J-PAL compare to other organization that here is more supporting environment.
cons: J-PAL give us short term contract every time and after 90 days renew the contract.

pros:
- Great place to gain field experience
- Get to learn diff parts of an org - admin, finance, research 
- Very supportive team and colleagues
cons:
- Work hours can be crazy and get out of hand if team is not supportive
- Many times it may feel that you've been thrown into the sea and have to figure it out yourself.

review_title: Learn a ton about doing field research
pros: Incredible learning experience compared to other research jobs, especially if you are involved in data collection. Opportunities to manage teams and operations typically not available to young professionals just out of undergrad.
cons: Unless you are co-located with your PI you get relatively little support from a supervisor, and most professional development has to be self-led.

review_title: Amazing place to learn and kickstart career
pros:
- smart coworkers
- great office culture/good place to make friends
- flexible hours
- good mix of fieldwork 
- skills you learn on the job make you exceptionally marketable for grad school in the US/any jobs in policy and research.
cons: - salary is a bit low for the sector

review_title: Awesome company with a great mission, expect long hours
pros: Great, intelligent people. Interesting work and projects. Many different divisions (data analytics, policy, research, etc.) Fulfilling research with a great mission. Top name for development research
cons: Limited mobility (need grad school degree), academic environment is slightly stuffy, long work hours

pros: Lots to learn, great set of people, cutting edge policy research, interact with PIs,  policy makers and senior folks in the industry, challenging fieldwork, opportunities to learn new things, inputs are taken and acted upon by management
cons: Challenging and hard work, travel and could have long hours, career paths within JPAL are not super clear

review_title: Great place to learn and contribute
pros:
Opportunity to work with the best minds in research.
Wide variety of projects in key sectors. Steep learning curve in research.
Open culture.
Employee friendly.
Wonderful colleagues.
Flexi working options available when needed.
cons:
Sometimes when overlooked, bad managers spoil the work culture and team dynamics.
Slow growth for support functions.

pros: You will get good exposure of  work. Most of their work is related to RCT's .You will get  Good recommendation of letter, for those who are planning for Phd. abroad.
cons: Difficult to enter into corporate again.Difficult choice to make between J-Pal and corporate.Tight work schedule and working hours are long.

pros:
-On the ground experience in development field research
-Great community of RAs worldwide
-Learn about research methods, design, implementation and analysis
-A serious challenge with major rewards
cons:
-Too little professional and personal support for RAs
-Heavy work load
-Underpaid

pros: Great Place to work at. The people are great, there is immense scope for taking new initiatives. There is a lot of transparency and ideas are encouraged.
cons: You may or may not be absorbed by the organisation when the contract ends

review_title: The fastest way to add tremendous value to your CV
pros: Inspiring co-workers, challenging environment, high-profile teams, government interaction
cons: Hard to see the impact of your work, employees are massively overworked and underpaid

review_title: The best social science research experience. But no place to move up.
pros: Direct contact with researhc community in the US.
cons: There is no place to grow within the institute.

pros: This is a action poverty lab to control the air pollution as well water
cons: Management is not so good

pros: J PAL NGO is the best Ngo for recearcher .This Ngo Work in All India working As a time
cons: My 7 Years experience in Ngo .As a time work in JPAL NGO.

pros: Working here is really exiting, you never stop learning, and you have access to the top economists on earth.
cons: Sometimes is hard to develop a career inside the institution.

pros: Typical perks, but they're mostly from MIT. Most people are friendly.
cons: A lot of favoritism. Two directors are extremely difficult people to work with and very discourteous. internal scandal makes it hard to take them seriously.

review_title: Extremely supportive and intellectually curious co-workers and work environment
pros:
- Supportive, collaborative work culture
- High expectations 
- Smart and passionate peers
cons: - Little room for upward mobility

review_title: Good friend, but not so good for learning
pros: Great co-worker, good  working environment
cons: not work-life balance, slave-like workloads

pros: Lots to learn and gain skills
cons: Less pay, too much work, every project experience is very different and depends on PIs

review_title: Asking the right question on development
pros:
Gain insight on policies that actually yield impact
Learn to deeply screen policies
Learn strategic partnership building
Gain access to high policy spheres
cons: I don't have specific downside

pros: Decent upward mobility if you have a masters
cons: Some colleagues are lazy and drag down the grop

review_title: Good for early career; please leave soon
pros:
Intellectually rigourous work
Given responsibilities early in your career
cons:
Experience depends on PIs you work with
Promotions and performance review is arbitrary
Management is horrible

pros: great skills to learn. connect with senior PIs
cons: Do not criticise the management. They don't like it.

pros: Great exposure to Academia and networking for those interested in pursuing a PHD
cons: Country offices can be a bit disorganized

pros: Able to get into the details of the research, everyone was friend.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: This is a greta place to work at.  i definitely recommend it
cons: Some problems related to food.

review_title: Pretty good for getting into grad school
pros: Strong network of professors and great group of RAs
cons: Terrible disorganization, experience depends on PI

pros: Great access to development specialists and academicians.
cons: High dependence on stage of work and commitment from Principal Investigators

pros: - Great research experience for budding researchers or who want to apply for graduate schools.
cons: - Limited interaction with PIs.

pros: Great colleagues, intellectual environment, cutting-edge research
cons: Flat hierarchy, not really a career job

pros: Good Culture, Good People, Room to Grow
cons: Low Pay, Some managers can be iffy

review_title: I loved working there! great place to work
pros: Great team and a high level of learning.
cons: Sometimes coordination was difficult among departments.

pros: There is lot of to learn
cons: No downside of company this is very good to learner

pros: Development projects and econometrics, grad school opps
cons: Development projects take a long time to finish!

pros: Serious Responsibilities, great recommendations, and independent work
cons: Long, uncertain hours and minimum growth

pros: Operate the operation of district dish tv & d2h settop boxes service.
cons: 24 hrs in service managemnt

job_title: Research Support Assistant in North Goa
pros: Will learn how to be more and more productive.
cons: May have to face very high expectations

pros: Very research oriented and organized place to work
cons: Work life balance is a bit of an issue

pros:
